results.title: Marc Chagall
results.creator_credit: Kim Evans, LWT and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
At a time when the world was turning toward Modernism. artist Marc Chagall had decided to finally leave his native Russia for Paris, the epi-centre of the art world at the turn of the 20th Century. Having suffered a poor and repressed childhood as a Russian Jew marginalised by poverty and cultural dissent Chagall’s iconography differed from his contemporaries. Whilst employing essentially a cubist surface his subject matter was deeply personal drawing on his life experiences. This documentary explores Chagall’s personal vision as artist and storyteller charting his career through his paintings, set and costume designs and stain glass work. Edited and presented by Melvyn Bragg.

results.title: Christian Boltanski
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
A comprehensive documentary on one of the most important contemporary artists of 20th Century France, Christian Boltanski. Interviewed by Melvyn Bragg, Boltanski’s childhood influences, mostly the affects of the Holocaust on society in post-war France are explored in direct reference to a series of Boltanski’s work spanning over a period of 30 years. Boltanski’s passion for ethnology, collections and death, as themes central to his art, are discussed in relationship to his work. The subtlety of broad themes are constantly explored in his work: the nature of the killer, heroes and villains, quantifying loss. Boltanski uses mostly photographs in his installation pieces. Works featured in the documentary: ‘Shadows’ (1985); ‘Sans Souci’ (1991); ‘The Reserves’ (1993); ‘The Dead Swiss’; ‘The Art of the Venice Biennale 1938’ (1993); ‘Comical Skits’(1974).

results.title: Vermeer: the spell of a woman
results.creator_credit: Christopher Burstall, BBC and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Written by Sir Lawrence Gowing, “Vermeer, the Spell of Woman”, is focussed on the women as the subjects driving Vermeer’s paintings. Producing only 2 paintings per year (completing 27 before his death at only 43 years of age), Vermeer’s view of the world was expressed mostly through his female subjects. He always painted the people and objects around him, the private world of the everyday. His secluded and private subjects were given tangible stages. Complex perceptions were implied in these ‘ordinary’ subjects providing the tensions evident in real life. The paradox in his work between the intimacy depicted in the subject and the equal impersonality of the subject, being the mystery behind the unknown is explored throughout the documentary. Vermeer’s need to look at the detail in his life in order to exact a truth about human nature is evidenced here. In using the camera obscura in the process of painting his subjects, Vermeer allowed himself to shift his focus and capture the light that fragments what we see, what decorates the ordinary and transports and captivates a viewer’s gaze.

results.title: Ben Nicholson 1894-1982
results.creator_credit: John Read, Anne Balfour Fraser, Arts Council of Great Britain and RM Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This is the story of the modern English artist Ben Nicholson as remembered by some of his closest friends and colleagues: Patrick Heron, Andras Kalman, Sir Leslie Martin, Angela Verren and Dr Felicitas Vogler. At the height of his career, Nicholson was one of the few artists to obtain international recognition with his contributions to modern art. His ‘white wall reliefs’ of the 30’s were his most notable work. This documentary traces his life and movements across Europe from Cumberland, St Ives to Switzerland - landscapes that were to influence his work greatly and remain a source of inspiration during his lifetime. Written and narrated by John Read.

results.title: Quiet man with welding torch: a portrait of sculptor Julio Gonzalez 1876-1942
results.creator_credit: Laurence Boulting, William Leeson, Barrie Gavin, RM Arts and Waveband Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
The spanish artist Julio Gonzalez (1876-1942) has been recognised along with Brancusi and Picasso as one of the most important sculptors of the 20th Century in his generation responsible for ‘opening the most doors for 20th century sculpture’. A man of acute sensibilities whose ‘aesthetics of poverty’ gave birth to a legacy that celebrated found junk-metal and iron scraps making elegant and poignant sculptural forms. The documentary examines the sculptors past as jeweller and his growing aesthetic and technical methods throughout his career. A fearful man who lived a simple life away from publicity and the art world after the volatile period surrounding the world wars in Europe and the Spanish civil war. Narrated by Lyndon Brook.

results.title: Roseland
results.creator_credit: Octavio Iturbe, Walter Verdin, Wim Vandekeybus, Audiovisuele Dienst K U Leuven and Alive From Off Center, Beeldhuis, Twin Cities Public Television, Ultima Vez and VRT
results.brief_description: Ultima Vez is a dance company formed by director, choreographer, actor and photographer Wim Vandekeybus in 1985. This dance video, made from the material of Vandekeybus’ first three choreographies with the company, places these performances in the remarkable setting of a dilapidated Brussels cinema which had been abandoned for the past twenty years. Using a range of cinematic techniques, the film radiates a particular fascination of its own, transforming the theatrical energy of the stage choreography into a dynamic screen experience. For more information go to http://www.ultimavez.com/

results.title: Chillida
results.creator_credit: Laurence Boulting, William Leeson, ETB Euskal Telebista (Basque Television) and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This is a fine introduction to the work of renowned Basque sculptor Eduardo Chillida (born 1914), who works mainly with iron, clay, and stone to create both monumental and smaller works of art. Chillida’s art is primarily conceptual and not functional. We learn through his articulate commentary that Chillida is interested in space, time and the unknown. He begins the creative process without imposing preconceived thoughts, aims or ideas. Rather, Chillida seeks to break away from tradition, habit, expectation and repetition to discover and enter the unknown, the unseen. His approach is philosophical, and the result is impressive. The documentary also provides an overview of Chillida’s childhood, family background, his affinity with his hometown San Sebastian, and his working methods. The local history and traditions of his hometown are an important influence on his work as is its natural wonders. The abstract minimalism of Chillida’s art is spiritual, and a wondrous attempt to grapple with the mysteries and beauty of the world of nature.

results.title: Point counterpoint: the life and work of Georges Seurat 1859-1891
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner, BBC and RM Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
This documentary of Suerat not only addresses the man as artist and one of the most important of France in the late 19th Century but also of his person - a man of mystery, a revolutionary who was also both modest and self-effacing by nature. Combining both the impressionists love of light and colour with his own ‘scientific’ system for colour exploration Suerat welcomed the post-revolutionary era, and not unlike the Eiffel tower that became a symbol for modern France, Seurat was to symbolise the shift toward the modern in the art world. Written and narrated by David Thompson.

results.title: The Story of fashion. Vol 02: the art and sport of fashion
results.creator_credit: Eila Hershon, Roberta Guerra and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
In the second episode of this three part series presented by Karl Lagerfeld, the influence of film and television stars within fashion is discussed. From the designers who outfitted Claudette Colbert, Joan Crawford and Josephine Baker to Nolan Miller, head costume designer for “Dynasty”. The rise of the celebrity role model and the creation of a certain style is also explored. It highlights the influence of individual designers such as Jean Patou and Coco Chanel and also examines the relationship between fashion style and history, art and photography. Includes interviews with Pierre Cardin and other leading industry players.

results.title: Miro: theatre of dreams
results.creator_credit: Robin Lough, Christopher Martin, BBC-TV, Poorhouse Productions and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
A biographical documentary on Spanish painter and sculptor Joan Miro (1893-1983), renowned for his part in the 1920s surrealist movement in Paris in his exploration of the inner world of dreams and the unconscious in a range of works. The documentary traces his involvement at the age of 85 in putting together a strongly political theatrical piece with young actors under the banner of Claca theatre, a theatre ideally aimed to translate to performance anywhere and as a surreal vision of traditional Catalonian folk culture. The program discusses his fascination with this historical theatrical form from childhood and the seriousness behind the concept of monsters in the Claca production which underlines his opposition to tyrants in Spanish history, a reference to the fascist invasion of Spain in 1936 and Franco’s subsequent leadership. Interwoven with the coverage of the progress of Claca’s production is a very personal study of Miro’s life and work through interviews with Miro himself on the inspirations for his work from childhood to recent history and the underlying philosophy in his work of not distorting life but seeing it with the third eye, that is seeing it as a veil in the world of dreams. The program also explores the contents of his studio in Majorca, his working materials and the items he collected from travel abroad. A meditation on their reference points in his work and artistic process is presented through stills of his work and visuals of him working in his studio and discussing his instinctive style of painting which draws from ordinary life to create a surrealist poetic. Footage of the premiere of Claca Theatre when Catalonia returned to an independent state and a presentation of Miro’s thoughts at the time closes the program and underlines the continued significance and intensity of Miro’s artistic vision of history interwoven with the immediacy of everyday life.
